data.text: https://t.co/NDbkEfTg4M
Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s monetary policy press conference https://t.co/qijJCmHsgs https://t.co/CXaLtJKFeN
Watch again: Draghi on how forward guidance reduces uncertainty https://t.co/1nEpwDfMPM
Watch again: Draghi on why central bank independence matters https://t.co/2Yd8QuAHpR
Watch again: Draghi on completing the Economic and Monetary Union https://t.co/mjohqAtkqX
Watch again: Draghi on the risks of a hard Brexit https://t.co/YxyDycXn3i
Introductory statement Mario Draghi to the press conference https://t.co/ShDDVSG0XH

Draghi: If the lack of solutions in the negotiations around Brexit continues and remains as the end date gets closer, the private sector itself will have to prepare for a hard Brexit... I would not call it a big financial stability risk, but financial uneasiness
Draghi: We have not discussed the adjustment of the capital key, but I would be surprised if we were to use a different concept than the capital key for the asset purchases
Draghi: Our monetary union remains fragile if it is not completed
Draghi: Credible forward guidance reduces uncertainty.
Draghi: Forward guidance on interest rates and on asset purchases has anchored the short-term part of the yield curve while QE has addressed the long-term part. It has served us very well.

Draghi: Central bank independence in terms of how to comply and deliver their mandates — in our case price stability — and in choosing the most appropriate instruments is crucial for the effectiveness of monetary policy
Draghi: We have not discussed what we are going to do next, will do so when we get the next round of projections
Draghi: The end of QE is not a selective measure to any specific country, but a monetary policy instrument

Draghi: When we look at surrounding developments, we see negotiated wages keep going up, the labour market keeps expanding. ... So we should have no doubt about our confidence that inflation is gradually reaching our aim
Draghi: Yes there is weaker momentum, yes there is weaker survey data, but is this enough to make us change the baseline scenario? The answer is no.
Draghi: An ample degree of monetary accommodation is still necessary for the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term
Draghi: On the basis of current futures prices for oil, annual rates of headline inflation are likely to hover around the current level over the coming months

Draghi: Risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook can still be assessed as broadly balanced, at the same time, risks relating to protectionism, vulnerabilities in emerging markets and financial market volatility remain prominent
Draghi: Our monetary policy measures continue to underpin domestic demand, private consumption is fostered by ongoing employment growth and rising wages
Draghi: Incoming information, while somewhat weaker than expected, remains overall consistent with an ongoing broad-based expansion of the euro area economy and gradually rising inflation pressures

Draghi: We intend to reinvest principal payments from maturing securities for an extended period of time after end of net asset purchases, and in any case for as long as necessary to maintain favourable liquidity conditions and an ample degree of monetary accommodation

Draghi: We will continue to make net purchases at the new monthly pace of €15 billion until end-December 2018; we anticipate that, subject to incoming data confirming our medium-term inflation outlook, we will then end net purchases
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Mario Draghi explains today’s monetary policy decisions https://t.co/WLL4r50r1S
Coming up in 15 minutes: ECB President Mario Draghi explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/wutA4Gl4h9
Monetary policy decisions https://t.co/OsY18SwL6V
Later today: watch live as ECB President Mario Draghi explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/YBVt5yOWoS
Monetary developments in the euro area (Sept 2018) https://t.co/mS0kUmMvP0
We're @Sibos discussing our new instant payment settlement service #TIPS. Take a look at this thread to find out more! https://t.co/0DtROuTrPe

Banks reported that the ECB’s monetary policy measures – including the asset purchase programme & negative deposit facility rate – continued to support bank lending volumes: https://t.co/CBwdpBFgQ1 https://t.co/RBYg8ZR8pD

Companies’ demand for loans also increased in Q3 2018, driven mainly by fixed investment, inventories, working capital, M&A activity and low interest rates. https://t.co/K5vym7AL8v https://t.co/EUo9kZFMK7

Demand for housing loans increased less than in Q2 2018 but was around the long-term average, mainly because of low interest rates, favorable housing market prospects and strong consumer confidence. https://t.co/lFiOAsbCOG https://t.co/Q4TNuSchyw

Credit conditions continue to ease for companies, less so for housing loans. For Q4 2018 banks expect broadly unchanged credit standards for firms and a net easing for housing loans. https://t.co/nBVlm3SYaD https://t.co/NAVdONkeLV

We asked 147 banks about changes in their lending conditions, loan demand and the impact of the ECB’s monetary policy measures during Q3 2018. Find out what the banks said in the Bank Lending Survey: https://t.co/1tx3jGfSqw https://t.co/jdHY3ADpim

Discover more about the exciting world of statistics on the euro area statistics website, where you’ll be able to find charts revealing the dynamics of inflation in the euro area https://t.co/71BcN0imU1 https://t.co/EXVdb9cZ7y

Today we’re celebrating #EuropeanStatisticsDay! At the ECB we try to make statistics understandable to everyone. Come and check out why we think statistics matter https://t.co/4qUgBKHzKR https://t.co/yzcUhfoERt

The insight highlights the value of euro area listed shares, which has surpassed its pre-crisis peak to reach 8 trillion euro, although it still varies a lot across countries https://t.co/dfFsEyyR03 https://t.co/2ZzNrpMX7E

Tomorrow we will be celebrating #EuropeanStatisticsDay! Ahead of that we have published a new, interactive insight into euro area statistics which is available in all EU languages https://t.co/dfFsEyyR03 https://t.co/TgFRnQuX2O
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Aug 2018) https://t.co/aBJ8IuebmM
Does Pepper the Humanoid feel emotions? Hear him talk about his dream job! #AI (2/3) https://t.co/Q9FZ3hgeOR

#ArtificialIntelligence can make us more efficient by analysing massive sets of data and automating simple tasks. During the ECB IT Forum staff event we took a moment to look at the potential and implications of new technologies using #AI. Have a look! (1/3) https://t.co/N62d0h9l5x
Speech Peter Praet: Economic policymaking under uncertainty https://t.co/SnKrttyOdn
Read more about #TIPS, the service we’re offering to banks from the end of next month to make your bank transfers instant https://t.co/dbGdNZPiw8 https://t.co/XKgCg7OQe2

We’ll be @Sibos next week, discussing the future of #instantpayments and the arrival of our new instant payment settlement service #TIPS. Follow @TARGET_ECB for all the latest news direct from Sydney https://t.co/7A40oHO5LI https://t.co/RBZVFPPRvg
Semi-annual update of the breakdown of holdings of the Corporate Sector Purchase Programme (CSPP) by sector, rating and country of risk https://t.co/Z00zrV1Hds (Excel file)

We also wanted to explain a little about our work. We talked to locals about how the ECB has made it more attractive for banks to lend to businesses. This means better conditions for businesses, helping to create more jobs. (3/3) https://t.co/iq00jzLiKg
Here’s our travelogue (2/3) https://t.co/lGsWJHQjZd

(THREAD) How do our policies affect you locally? We went on the road with board member Benoît Cœuré to find out. Our destination: the Vorwerk factory in Cloyes-sur-le-Loir, France. (1/3) https://t.co/hOzrmL1Dms

There are concerns that the leverage ratio – which includes repo assets – has had a negative impact on the functioning of repo markets. But what would be the implications of removing repo assets from the leverage ratio? Find out here https://t.co/fE3wqju0s0

The investment fund sector has expanded rapidly over the past decade and funds have increased their investments in riskier and less liquid assets. Are macroprudential liquidity tools needed for investment funds? https://t.co/gz9TJXHeW5 https://t.co/MpifIGxHfz

Evidence suggests that some global systemically important banks, or G-SIBs, are using “window-dressing” to avoid more stringent capital requirements. What does this involve and how could it affect financial stability? https://t.co/w5slqlEssI

Our latest Macroprudential Bulletin explores potential macroprudential liquidity tools for investment funds, how some global systemically important banks try to avoid additional capital buffers, whether repo assets should be removed from the leverage ratio https://t.co/g1RCYoGowJ https://t.co/cl3wnRuOwr
